q: What can you do to treat a blister yourself?
a: You can cover blisters with a soft plaster or padded dressing, wash your hands before touching a burst blister, and allow the fluid in a burst blister to drain before covering it.

q: How can a pharmacist help with blisters?
a: A pharmacist can recommend a plaster or dressing to cover the blister while it heals. They may suggest using a hydrocolloid dressing to protect the blister, reduce pain, and speed up healing.

q: How can you check if you have a blister?
a: Blisters are small pockets of clear fluid under a layer of skin. You can visually inspect for blisters or blood blisters, which are filled with blood instead of clear fluid. An infected blister may be hot and filled with green or yellow pus.

q: When should you see a GP for a blister?
a: You should see a GP if the blister is very painful, keeps recurring, looks infected, is in an unusual place (like eyelids, mouth, or genitals), appears for no reason, or is caused by a burn or scald, sunburn, or allergic reaction.

q: What can a GP do for a blister?
a: A GP might burst a large or painful blister using a sterilized needle. If the blister is infected, they may prescribe antibiotics. They can also provide treatment and advice if the blisters are caused by a medical condition.

q: Which medical conditions can cause blisters?
a: Conditions that can cause blisters include chickenpox, cold sores, genital herpes, bullous impetigo, pompholyx, scabies, and hand, foot and mouth disease.

q: How can you prevent blisters?
a: To prevent blisters, you can wear comfortable and well-fitting shoes, gradually break in new shoes, wear thick socks during exercise, dust talcum powder in your socks if you have sweaty feet, and wear protective gloves during exercise or when using tools at work.

q: How can you treat a blister yourself?
a: You can treat a blister yourself by covering it with a soft plaster or padded dressing, washing your hands before touching a burst blister, and allowing the fluid in a burst blister to drain before covering it.

q: What should you not do when you have a blister?
a: You should not burst a blister yourself, peel the skin off a burst blister, pick at the edges of the remaining skin, or wear the shoes or use the equipment that caused your blister until it heals.

q: What can a pharmacist recommend to protect a blister?
a: A pharmacist can recommend a plaster or dressing to cover the blister while it heals. A hydrocolloid dressing can help protect the blister, reduce pain, and speed up healing.

q: How can you check if you have a blister?
a: Blisters are small pockets of clear fluid under a layer of skin. Blood blisters may look red or black and are filled with blood instead of clear fluid. An infected blister can be hot and filled with green or yellow pus, and the surrounding skin may look red.

q: When should you see a GP for a blister?
a: You should see a GP if the blister is very painful or keeps coming back, the skin looks infected, the blister is in an unusual place, several blisters have appeared for no reason, or a blister was caused by a burn, scald, sunburn, or an allergic reaction.

q: What treatment can a GP provide for a blister?
a: A GP might burst a large or painful blister using a sterilized needle and prescribe antibiotics if the blister is infected. They can also offer treatment and advice if blisters are caused by a medical condition.

q: What medical conditions can cause blisters?
a: Medical conditions that can cause blisters include chickenpox, cold sores, genital herpes, bullous impetigo, pompholyx, scabies, and hand, foot and mouth disease.

q: Why do blisters develop?
a: Blisters develop to protect damaged skin and help it heal. They are mostly caused by friction, burns, and skin reactions.

q: How can you prevent blisters on your feet or hands?
a: To prevent blisters on your feet or hands, you can wear comfortable, well-fitting shoes, wear new shoes for short periods of time until they're comfortable, wear thick socks during exercise, dust talcum powder in your socks if you get sweaty feet, and wear protective gloves when you exercise or use tools at work.

q: How can you treat a blister yourself?
a: You can cover the blister with a soft plaster or padded dressing, wash your hands before touching a burst blister, and allow the fluid in a burst blister to drain before covering it. However, do not burst the blister yourself or pick at the edges of the remaining skin.

q: How can a pharmacist help with blisters?
a: A pharmacist can recommend a plaster or dressing to cover the blister while it heals. They may suggest a hydrocolloid dressing to protect the blister, reduce pain, and speed up healing.

q: How can you check if you have a blister?
a: Blisters are small pockets of clear fluid under a layer of skin. Blood blisters may appear red or black and contain blood instead of clear fluid. An infected blister can be hot and filled with green or yellow pus.

q: What should you do if you have a painful or infected blister?
a: If a blister is very painful or infected, you should see a GP. They can provide relief by bursting a large or painful blister using a sterilized needle, and prescribe antibiotics if the blister is infected.

q: What medical conditions can cause blisters?
a: Medical conditions that can cause blisters include chickenpox, cold sores, genital herpes, bullous impetigo, pompholyx, scabies, and hand, foot and mouth disease.

q: What causes blisters and how can you prevent them?
a: Blisters are mostly caused by friction, burns, and skin reactions. To prevent them, you can wear comfortable, well-fitting shoes, wear new shoes for short periods of time, wear thick socks during exercise, and use talcum powder in your socks if you have sweaty feet. Additionally, wearing protective gloves when exercising or using tools can also help prevent blisters.

q: When should you see a GP for a blister?
a: You should see a GP if a blister is very painful, keeps coming back, is infected with green or yellow pus, has red skin around it (which can be harder to see on darker skin tones), is in an unusual place (such as your eyelids, mouth, or genitals), or if several blisters have appeared for no reason.

q: What should you not do when you have a blister?
a: When you have a blister, you should not burst it yourself, peel the skin off a burst blister, pick at the edges of the remaining skin, or wear the shoes or use the equipment that caused the blister until it heals.

q: What can a GP do for blisters caused by a medical condition?
a: A GP can offer treatment and advice if blisters are caused by a medical condition. They may prescribe appropriate medications or recommend specific treatments to manage the underlying condition.

q: What can an infected blister lead to if left untreated?
a: An infected blister, if left untreated, can lead to a skin infection or blood infection. It is important not to ignore an infected blister and seek treatment from a medical professional.
